Award.AwardTitle: Probability Theory and Statistics in High and Infinite Dimensions: Empirical Processes Theory and Beyond
Award.AbstractNarration:
The conference on "Probability Theory and Statistics in High and Infinite Dimensions: Empirical Processes Theory and Beyond" will focus on empirical processes and other methods of high-dimensional probability and their role in a variety of problems related to statistical inference for high-dimensional data as well as to nonparametric inference. The conference will be held on June 23-25, 2014 at the Center for Mathematical Sciences, University of Cambridge, UK. The list of topics includes concentration inequalities, exponential and moment bounds for Gaussian, empirical and other related processes, nonasymptotic bounds for random matrices, complexity penalization methods and oracle inequalities in high-dimensional inference, sparse recovery and low rank matrix recovery, high-dimensional problems in machine learning, nonparametric estimation and hypotheses testing, Bayesian nonparametrics.

High-dimensional probability and statistics have had impact far beyond mathematical sciences. The methods of high-dimensional probability have been crucial in understanding the performance of new machine learning algorithms and in the design of contemporary methods of analysis of big data. Bringing together researchers who have made and are currenly making important contributions to this area would facilitate the exchange of ideas leading to much better understanding of the role of high-dimensional phenomena in statistical inference and machine learning. The conference would be especially beneficial for junior participants entering these research areas. This award will support the participation of approximately twenty US-based participants in the conference.

Conference web site: www.statslab.cam.ac.uk/~nickl/Site/2014.html

POR.DRECONTENT:
The conference on "Probability Theory and Statistics in High and Infinite Dimensions: Empirical Processes Theory and Beyond" focused on empirical processes and on the methods of high-dimensional probability and their role in a variety of problems related to statistical inference for high-dimensional data as well as to nonparametric inference. The conference was held on June 23-25, 2014 at the Center for Mathematical Sciences, University of Cambridge, UK. There were a total of 95 participants representing 16 countries. 29 invited speakers presented 30-minute lectures. 
The goal of the conference was to bring together researchers who have made and are making major contributions to the development of empirical and related classes of stochastic processes, theory of U-statistics, concentration inequalities, nonparametric and high-dimensional inference, and statistical learning theory.


Intellectual Merit: High-dimensional probability and statistics have been major sources of deep and powerful mathematical ideas that penetrated many active applied research areas such as compressed sensing, collaborative filtering, network analysis, classification methods in machine learning. The conference facilitated exchanges of such ideas between mathematicians, statisticians and computer scientists and it is likely to lead to research collaborations.   


Broader Impacts: The conference was especially beneficial for junior researchers (junior faculty, post docs, and graduate students) by giving them an opportunity to attend talks in the cutting edge areas of high-dimensional probability and statistics given by leading researchers, to have discussions and interactions with them and with each other. The grant provided funding to cover travel expenses for participants from the US. In total, 18 participants from the US institutions were supported, including seven junior participants, who received about 40% of the total amount of funding. 


Last Modified: 06/05/2015
Modified by: Vladimir Koltchinskii
